Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to C. Alisha Quandt is "Fungal community variation associated with the digestive tracts of a large collection of predatory, marine snails." The host institution for this fellowship is the University of Michigan (UM), and the sponsoring scientist is Timothy Y. James.

Research into vertebrate microbiomes has led to the discovery of previously unidentified fungal and bacterial communities that are not only beneficial to their multicellular hosts, but in some cases, essential. Studies of microbial communities associated with invertebrates, however, are rare but offer an important opportunity for discovery. The fellowship research seeks to use existing collections of Conus, a well-studied genus of predatory marine snails, to characterize their fungal gut communities and their functional profile to determine if these are correlated with host genetics, diet, or geographical distribution. Data are being collected from preserved specimens about the fungal communities associated with marine mollusks. Mollusca, one of the largest animal phyla, can have broad geographic ranges and several mollusks have become invasive throughout the world, sometimes with devastating economic and ecological effects; yet little is known about their microbial communities. This pioneering study is made possible by the existing collection and promises a breadth and depth of sampling never before conducted on any mollusk genus as well as the first culture-independent study of fungi associated with mollusks. Results have the potential to unearth not only several new species of fungi, but possibly undescribed lineages, and increase understanding of the functional capabilities of the fungal communities associated with mollusks, possibly linking Conus diet with functional characteristics of the microbiome. A connection between microbiome and diet may explain how mollusks are able to thrive in newly invaded habitats.

Training goals and career advance activities include gaining skills in new experimental systems and management skills, including both research and museum collection management. Educational outreach includes undergraduate students through funding from the UM Undergraduate Research Opportunity Program (UROP) program and 4th to 6th grade girls through the Females Excelling More in Math Engineering and the Sciences (FEMMES) program at UM at after school education events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to use existing, extensive collections of a well-studied group of predatory marine snails called Cone snails, to characterize their microbiomes and determine if these are correlated with snail genetics, diet, or environment. This project utilized Cone snail specimens collected from around the world preserved at the University of Michigan Museum of Zoology (UMMZ) which houses a large and nationally recognized collection of marine and terrestrial mollusks.

The major objectives of the project were to: (1) Identify which fungi are commonly associated with the digestive tracts of available species of marine Cone snails, preserved at the University of Michigan Museum of Zoology, (2) Determine if Cone snail relatedness or geographical distribution causes greater variation in fungal community, and (3) Determine how fungal and bacterial community composition and function correlate with Cone snail diet. We determined that there are a handful of fungi that are a part of the core microbiome of these Cone snails, and interestingly one of these fungi is commonly found in the skin of vertebrate animals including humans. While analysis is ongoing, analyzing data from more than 60 species, and hundreds of specimens indicates that neither geography or relatedness is driving the microbiome community structure. There is some correlation between diet and microbiome richness, but it is not statistically significant likely due to the relatively few available specimens of some diet types. At the broadest sense, this project provided support for the ability of researchers to successfully use preserved museum specimens for microbiome research both, and also illuminated possible challenges. For example, this project found a statistically lower number of bacteria in samples that had been preserved for more than 15 years, despite being preserved in ethanol. This finding could have huge implications for future microbiome studies using any type of preserved specimens.

This project accomplished three training objectives for the postdoctoral fellow. (1) The fellow gained skills in working with preserved, non-fungal specimens. Through the optimization of fungal DNA amplification from the preserved museum snail collections, the fellow developed protocols and skills that have provided the proper training for future work involving previously unexamined hosts. (2) The fellow also developed interdisciplinary research skills. This project provided the opportunity to work with specialists in another field of biology, and provided training in interdisciplinary research, and has led the fellow into pursuing new directions for part of her research program. (3) Finally, the fellow also cultivated research independence, project management skills, and mentorship experience. The fellow managed use of the museum collections and coordinated research and publications with UMMZ malacologists, the sponsoring mycologist, and an undergraduate researcher. An undergraduate researcher was also trained, supervised, and mentored by the fellow.

There were many broader impacts of this project, including the training of one undergraduate student with partial funding from the UM Undergraduate Research Opportunity Program (UROP) program. The fellow trained the UROP student in DNA extraction, PCR amplification, and community sequencing and statistical analyses, and he has been included as authors on presentations of the results of this project and will be a co-author on publications resulting from his contribution to the research. Another broader impact of this project has been the mentorship the fellow has provided by participating in a bi-weekly mentoring circle as a part of the University of Michigan chapter of the Association for Women in Science (AWIS). This group of graduate students and post-docs discussed relevant literature and topics related to women and other underrepresented groups in science, and the circle also served as a chance for members to share experiences and ask questions of other women scientists in similar fields. The fellow was also invited and served as a panelist on an AWIS panel for graduate students about being a postdoctoral researcher. The fellow also volunteered as a part of the Females Excelling More in Math Engineering and the Sciences (FEMMES) program at UM, through which the fellow will educate 4th - 6th grade girls in genetics, DNA replication and translation, and STEM careers at after school education events. In addition, the fellow has lectured on different aspects of fungal biology on multiple occasions in an Ann Arbor high school Advanced Placement (AP) Environmental Science class during the reporting period. Lessons plans are freely available to other educators on the fellow’s personal website. Finally, the fellow also guest lectured on fungi to two classes at an Ann Arbor middle school.
